abstract: A 2 × 2 3-dB coupler is one of the essential photonic components, as a building block of Mach-Zehnder interferometers, to realize large-scale photonic integrated circuits. Unlike typical 2 × 2 3-dB couplers based on direction couplers or multimode interference couplers, adiabatic couplers offer various advantages such as broadband operation and superior fabrication tolerance thanks to their unique operating mechanism of adiabatic mode evolution. However, an adiabatic coupler typically requires a long device length for ideal adiabatic operation without the excitations of unwanted modes. Here, we report on a compact 2 × 2 3-dB adiabatic coupler designed using the shortest mode transformer method. By optimizing the profile of the waveguide widths and the gap spacing, the compact 3-dB coupler was designed with a short coupling length of 23.2 μm. The fabricated device exhibits a 3-dB splitting ratio with less than ± 0.3 dB power oscillation and a low excess loss of 0.23 dB over a broad wavelength range of 1485–1620 nm. To the best of our knowledge, our coupler has the shortest length among the adiabatic couplers with a minimum feature size of 200 nm, reported to date.

In Ki Kim , Dong Uk Kim, Vinh Huu Nguyen, Sangyoon Han, and Tae Joon Seok , Member, IEEE
Abstract—A 2 × 2 3-dB coupler is one of the essential photonic
components, as a building block of Mach-Zehnder interferometers,
to realize large-scale photonic integrated circuits. Unlike typical
2 × 2 3-dB couplers based on direction couplers or multimode
interference couplers, adiabatic couplers offer various advantages
such as broadband operation and superior fabrication tolerance
thanks to their unique operating mechanism of adiabatic mode
evolution. However, an adiabatic coupler typically requires a long
device length for ideal adiabatic operation without the excitations
of unwanted modes. Here, we report on a compact 2 × 23 - d B
adiabatic coupler designed using the shortest mode transformer
method. By optimizing the proﬁle of the waveguide widths and
the gap spacing, the compact 3-dB coupler was designed with a
short coupling length of 23.2 µm. The fabricated device exhibits
a 3-dB splitting ratio with less than ± 0.3 dB power oscillation
and a low excess loss of 0.23 dB over a broad wavelength range
of 1485–1620 nm. To the best of our knowledge, our coupler has
the shortest length among the adiabatic couplers with a minimum
feature size of 200 nm, reported to date.
Index Terms—Integrated photonics circuit, silicon photonics,
waveguides, adiabatic coupler.
I. I NTRODUCTION
S
ILICON photonics is an attractive technology to realize
large-scale photonic integrated circuits thanks to its high
integration density and compatibility to advanced complem-
entary metal–oxide semiconductor (CMOS) processes [1]–[3].
On the silicon photonics platform, a 2 × 2 Mach–Zehnder
interferometer (MZI) is an essential component for active and
dynamic manipulation of light in various applications such
as optical switches, programmable photonic arrays, and linear
optical processing units [4]–[8]. As an MZI typically consists of

arms, a compact and low loss 2 × 2 coupler with an ideal
splitting ratio is a key building block to realize large-scale
silicon photonic systems. 2 × 2 couplers are commonly im-
plemented with directional couplers or multimode interference
(MMI) couplers. However, directional couplers have limited
bandwidths and their characteristics are highly sensitive to
fabrication imperfections [9]. Multimode interference (MMI)
couplers also have limited bandwidths and non-negligible inser-
tion losses. It has been reported that bandwidths of directional
couplers and MMI couplers can be widened by utilizing struc-
tures such as curved waveguides, asymmetric waveguides, and
subwavelength gratings (SWGs) [10]–[13]. However, they have
high insertion losses and low fabrication tolerances. Whereas
directional couplers and MMI couplers rely on mode beating
between their supermodes or multimodes, adiabatic couplers are
based on adiabatic mode evolution offering superior fabrication
tolerances, and wide bandwidths [14]. However, they typically
require long device lengths for their adiabatic mode evolution.
SWG-based compact adiabatic couplers have been proposed and
experimentally demonstrated [15], [16]. However, they have
features smaller than 100 nm which make them difﬁcult to
be fabricated in typical silicon photonic foundries. It has been
reported that adiabatic coupler designs having reduced lengths
based on optimizing the proﬁles of waveguide widths [17], [18].
There are adiabatic coupler designs that optimize not only width
proﬁles but also gap proﬁles, however, they either have small
feature sizes [19], [20] (e.g., 100 nm) or still have a long coupling
length [21].
In this paper, we proposed and experimentally demonstrated
a compact 2 × 2 3-dB adiabatic coupler based on the shortest
mode transformer method [22] on a 220-nm silicon-on-insulator
(SOI) platform. The coupling and total lengths of the proposed
device are 23.2 μm and 46.7 μm, respectively, with the minimum
feature size of 200 nm. The demonstrated device exhibits a
splitting ratio of 3 ±0.3 dB and an excess loss (EL) of 0.23 dB
over the wavelength range of 1485-1620 nm. To the best of our
knowledge, our coupler has the shortest length to date among
the adiabatic couplers with a minimum feature size of 200 nm.
In addition, our coupler is still shorter than most adiabatic
couplers with a minimum feature size of 100 nm except for Ref.
[20]. This compact size can be achieved with the optimized gap
proﬁle as well as the optimized waveguide width proﬁle.

II. D ESIGN AND SIMULATION RESULT
The device was designed for a SOI platform having a 220 nm-
thick silicon layer and 110 nm-deep partial etch depth for a trans-
verse electric (TE) mode operation. Fig. 1 shows the schematic
diagram of the proposed device consisting of ﬁve regions. For
Regions 1 and 5, we utilize conventional S-bends where the
gaps are varied from 1.5 μm to 640 nm, and from 200 nm to
1.5 μm, respectively. In Region 2, the gap spacing between the
two waveguides is adiabatically reduced from 640 nm to 200 nm
while the widths of the waveguides are ﬁxed. In Region 3, the
width of the upper waveguide (WG1) is adiabatically tapered
down while the width of the lower waveguide (WG2) remains
constant. The shortest adiabatic mode transformer method [22]
was applied to design Regions 2 and 3. Region 4 is the straight
section for stabilizing an optical mode after power is evenly
split into the two waveguides. In order to have an adiabatic mode
evolution in a 3-dB coupler, γ(≡ δ(z)

Therefore, we keep the gap to be ≥ 200 nm, which is readily

widths of the waveguides are preferred to be reasonably wide to
avoid excessive scattering losses. Therefore, we set the minimum

upper waveguide is greater than 600 nm. In this case, light can
be leaked to TE 1 mode of WG1 when light is inserted to WG2
(I2). Therefore, we limit the width of WG1 to be ≤ 550 nm.
In summary, we deﬁned the following constraints in addition
to Eq. (1) on our coupler design.
Constraint 1. For WG1, 400 nm ≤ width ≤ 550 nm.
Constraint 2. For WG2, width = 400 nm.
Constraint 3. Gap ≥ 200 nm.

For the case when the input light is inserted into I1 (I2),
we want to excite only the even (odd) mode. According to
Eq. (1), the fraction of power, ε, coupled into the odd (even)
mode is inversely proportional to the length of the coupler. The
existence of the power fraction in the unwanted mode causes
mode beating, which results in power oscillation between the
waveguides. In order to ﬁnd the length, zl, having sufﬁciently
low power oscillation, the transmission characteristics of the
coupler is calculated versus the length while maintaining the
γ proﬁle in Fig. 3(a), using an eigenmode expansion (EME)
solver. Fig. 4 clearly shows that the transmissions of the both
output ports converged to 3 dB with a reasonably small power
oscillation ( <0.2 dB) when the length is longer than 20 μm.
Therefore, we designed the length to be 23.2 μm, and the
corresponding lengths for Regions 2 and 3 are 7.2 μm and 16 μm,
respectively. We also veriﬁed the device characteristics by using
FDTD simulations. As shown in Fig. 5, the designed coupler
exhibits a 3-dB power splitting with an imbalance of less than
± 0.18 dB and an EL of less than 0.1 dB over the wavelength
range from 1485 to 1620 nm. Fig. 6 shows the simulated proﬁle
of the E-ﬁeld intensity when light is inserted into I1.
III. E XPERIMENTAL RESULT
The 2 × 23-dB adiabatic couplers were fabricated on an
8-inch SOI wafer using the fabrication facilities at the National
Nanofab Center (NNFC) in South Korea. A 70-nm-thick hard

mask layer of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was deposited ﬁrst
by low-pressure chemical vapor deposition (LPCVD). The hard
mask layer was patterned by a photolithography step with a
KrF scanner followed by a dry etching process. Subsequently,
rib waveguides were patterned by a 110-nm-deep silicon etch-
ing. Then, a second lithography step was done followed by
a 220-nm-deep silicon etching. Finally, the remaining hard
mask was removed via hydrogen ﬂuoride wet etching. Fig. 7
and Fig. 8 show the optical microscope images and scanning
electron microscope (SEM) images of the fabricated devices.
For the device characterization, a 127- μm pitch 48-channel
polarization-maintaining (PM) ﬁber array was used for con-
sistent ﬁber-to-chip coupling. TE-polarized light was coupled
through vertical grating couplers. The coupling efﬁciency of the
grating couplers was measured to be 6 dB/unit in a back-to-back
grating coupler pair on the same chip.
The power splitting ratio was characterized using the
unbalanced MZI shown in Fig. 7(a). Rib waveguides with a
width of 500 nm and a partial etch depth of 110 nm were em-
ployed for the two arms of the MZI, and their length difference
was designed to be 208 μm. The measured spectral responses
of the device are shown in Fig. 9. When light was inserted
at the ﬁrst input (I1), the device exhibited an extinction ratio
larger than 25 dB over the wavelength range of 1485–1620 nm,
corresponding to a power splitting ratio of 3 ± 0.25 dB. When
light was inserted at the second input (I2), the extinction ratio
was measured to be 23 dB over the same wavelength range,
corresponding to a power splitting ratio of 3 ± 0.3 dB. For the
reduced wavelength range of 1500–1540 nm, we observed a
high extinction ratio that exceeded 30 dB, which corresponds
to a splitting ratio of 3 ± 0.13 dB. The slight oscillation of
power splitting ratio is caused by unwanted mode scattering that
occurred before light is inserted to the Region2. This oscillation
can be reduced by increasing the initial gap, which is currently
designed to be 640 nm in the device. For the EL measurement,
we measured the output transmissions of a cascaded structure
of 16-stage 3-dB couplers. Subsequently, the EL of a single
3-dB coupler was calculated by dividing the total EL of the
cascaded structure by the number of the stage. Fig. 10 shows the
measured EL of the 3-dB coupler. We observed ELs less than
0.23 dB and 0.17 dB over the wavelength range of 1485–1620 nm
for light insertions into I1 and I2, respectively. The EL can be
reduced by employing more gradual waveguide bending at the
Region1/Region2 interface.

IV . C ONCLUSION
We have experimentally demonstrated a high-performance
and compact 2 × 2 silicon photonic 3-dB adiabatic coupler
based on the shortest mode transformer method. Using the
method thereof, the coupling length of the adiabatic coupler
can be reduced to a compact size of 23 μm with a relaxed CD
of 200 nm, which can be readily acceptable in existing silicon
photonics foundries. To the best of our knowledge, our coupler
has the shortest length to date among the adiabatic couplers with
a minimum feature size of 200 nm. In addition, our coupler is
still shorter than most adiabatic couplers with a minimum feature
size of 100 nm except for Ref. [20]. Furthermore, the coupler
indicated good performances, i.e., <± 0.3 dB oscillation and
<0.23 dB EL in a broad wavelength range of 1485–1620 nm.
Moreover, the oscillation of the power splitting ratio is reduced
to ±0.13 dB in the reduced wavelength range of 1500–1540 nm.
Our design methodology can be applied to variety of photonic
devices based on adiabatic couplers such as Y-splitter, photonic
switches, mode division multiplexers, and inversely-tapered
edge couplers for highly integrated photonic circuits.
